intro: Saracha zuccagniana, commonly known as the Zuccagni's saracha, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry soils and is often found in coastal areas. It produces small, white to greenish flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some parts of its range.
